fullText: This cheerfully synthetic show about bootleggers and blue bloods in the 1920s doesn't have an original thought in its head. But it does have Matthew Broderick and Kelli O'Hara, along with a glorious Gershwin score, and that turns out to be more than enough.
dtliExcerpt: This cheerfully synthetic show about bootleggers and blue bloods in the 1920s doesn't have an original thought in its head. But it does have Matthew Broderick and Kelli O'Hara, along with a glorious Gershwin score, and that turns out to be more than enough.
bwwExcerpt: Every now and then, a bubble of pure, tickling charm rises from the artificial froth of “Nice Work if You Can Get It,” the pastiche of a 1920s musical featuring songs by George and Ira Gershwin. Most of this show, which opened on Tuesday night at the Imperial Theater, registers as a shiny, dutiful trickle of jokes and dance numbers performed by talented people who don’t entirely connect with the whimsy of a bygone genre.
